So, I'm over at Gary & LPs house last night and, not unusually, the subject of politics, policies and Republicans came up. For those of you who aren't yet in the know, I truly, to the marrow of my bones, hate George W. Bush, his administration and his joke of a presidency. I also think most Republicans have their heads straight up their ass. If this offends you, cope, I said most. Both Gary and LP made excellent points. Gary's point: Welfare mothers are damned if they do and damned if they don't. Think about it, the anti-abortion circuit criminalizes single, pregnant women who choose to terminate a pregnancy, rather than give birth to the baby. It's murder, right? Well then these farktards turn around and criminalize single mothers for needing public assistance because the moms so dared to have the child. What's worse, they do everything in their power to un-empower her by trying to crush the modicum of benefits she may still have left. Unreal. Now before you pile on the crap, I'm not talking about these crazy women who bilk the system by pumping out kids at breakneck paces to support crack habits, I'm talking about regular women (I know a few), who got pregnant and need legitimate help to stay above water. And the first person to suggest she gives up the baby for adoption gets beat on the head with a pig bladder. Of course, a woman has a right to give up her child for adoption, not in dispute in the slightest, but to suggest a woman HAS TO, in lieu of going on public assistance, is hideous. Overall, I admit, Gary has a pretty damn good point. These jackasses win their argument no matter what the woman opts to do. Oh and hey, let's take away her abortion rights altogether and then fuck her over when she HAS to have the kid. Good times. Onward to LPs point. Welfare Mothers vs. 'Welfare Fathers' (I'm working on hard data to back this up, bear with me). So we have all the Republican'ts complaining about these single, welfare mothers eating up goobermint tax dollars and resources and how dare they and shame, shame, shame. Sinners deserve what they get, blah, blah, blah. OK, then by that SAME argument, let's explore the rich, white men/CEO principle, shall we? Huge corporations, run by CEOs making $40 MILLION DOLLARS A YEAR, move their 'headquarters' to Bermuda (read: shack with a phone) and create their lovely little tax shelter. They hunt down and exploit tax loopholes, like the one about their private jet. I'll use LP's example. Let's say it costs a private jet $9,000 to fly from LAX to LaGuardia. Thanks to the tax code, the company can write off almost 100% of the cost, making it CHEAPER to take a luxury private jet to LaGuardia than fly coach. Sound fair? So the theory is, and this is what we want the hard data for, for all the bitching the Republican'ts do about welfare mothers, they, in fact, are way bigger marauders and pillagers of the American tax stockpile, to the tune of BILLIONS. For all their bullshit finger pointing, if they would just stop being unethical weasels, we wouldn't have to worry about shit like, can single mom have a piece of chicken for her kid? Think about it, are they not ALSO using public assistance? YOU AND I PAY TO MAKE UP FOR THEIR NON-CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE COMMUNITY POT! Alas folks, the next time you hear some asshole bitching about abortion, ask them if they are willing to foot the bill to help the woman raise the kid, and if they're not willing to, suggest that they ask their CEO to pitch in, he's out picking the sand from his asscrack. What a world, people...what a world.

Last year, an old pal and neighbor of mine, John, lost his battle with AIDS. It was very sad because he never divulged his secret to me, despite regular e-mails, and I had to find out how sick he was through my NYC superintendent. I never got a chance to help him or talk with him about his fears and hopes. I hate knowing that someone I cared about had to die in such an awful, awful manner. He was surrounded by friends and family in the end but still, I wish I could have done somehting more. I will have a place for him inside this husk of a human being for always. Here's the dilemma: I still have his name and e-mail address in my computer's e-mail address book. I kinda don't want to delete it, not for any raison-morbid, just because it's a daily reminder of him and, in a way, if I delete his name and contact info, I feel like I'm going to somehow delete him from the universe of ever having been. Every time I see his name, I feel really sad, but maybe, that's good. We should remember our lost and remind ourselves to fight for those who aren't able to fight for themselves anymore. John Aaron DiLuzio is his name. Rest ye merry gentleman.

A new blogger buddy of mine and I were just having a conversation about the death penalty...my position on which I haven't considered with any depth in a long time. Here's what I said (Blogger Buddy is anti-death penalty, by the way): I TOTALLY hear and respect what you're saying and I've struggled with this for a long, long time. The system is flawed and so are people and most of the time, I can separate logic and reason from what's in the guts; however, I have a really hard time letting live someone who rapes and murders kids, child abusers and torturers...and now that DNA evidence is gaining respect for the accuracy of the technology, we know for as close to 100%, without having been there ourselves, as we're likely ever going to get. These people corrupt the spirit of our society, their cruelty divides culture and there is strong, strong evidence to suggest that their minds are irreparably damaged and no manner of money will afford correcting their broken nature. So then are we to be charged with keeping this filth, this tainter of spirits alive for the duration, affording him medical care that we won't even provide to our weakened grandmothers? There's something wrong there. The system is wrong, yes, but the system will always be wrong, lest we live in a complete police state where every move of every citizen is monitored. Life is indeed the most precious thing we've been afforded and a terrible crime has been committed anytime an innocent is taken unjustly yet, we send people to their death everyday...good, honor-bound people...policemen, firemen, soldiers...we sacrifice them for the greater good and it is never a beautiful story to tell when one falls, but somehow I wonder if I could tolerate a lamb mistakenly stepping in for the wolf if we catch more wolves and tend to the entire flock making the whole safer. ..first of all, is a great show, but that's not what this entry is about. On occasion, my life becomes something of a traveling side-show, I mean, Lobster-Boy , side-show. Nick and I are goobs. Really, we know this, we don't need your pity. Usually on Tuesdays, sometimes Sundays and an occasional Friday or two, we go to a certain pub in a certain part of town to play National Trivia Network . For those not in the 'know,' NTN is *shock,gasp,wheeze* a national network for trivia junkies and amateurs who compete individually in their own pub against other pubbers, and nationally, both as individuals and by establishment. I think our pub made the top ten once. Anyway, there are a LOT of smart fuckers who play, especially on Tuesdays, when all the brains show up and you have to struggle your ass not to be last (unless you're Nick, who is very deservedly in the top 3, often in first place on Tuesdays). However, on Fridays, it's more brain-friendly and casual and you get your rudimentary types...normally. There is one regular player who usually comes in Friday's but does an occasional off-night stint and sometimes we're all in the same place at the same time. Her name is Jenny. Jenny is a trivia whiz and has the highest ranking score(s) in the pub, by a long, long shot. Jenny has thick, long, sort of strawberry, washed-out blonde hair with chunky blonde highlights throughout her bangs. She wears thick, thick makeup, has long, long nails, fake ones...she's also got fake boobs and a five-o'clock shadow. Jenny is our transgendered friend. Jenny is sweet. Very, very sweet. If you're like Nick and I, you don't care that the stubble is growing back on her arms or that her paper-route is a drag (pun not intended). We don't care that she reads trashy romance novels at the bar, or that she repeats herself constantly about the woes of parking costs and delivering papers and drunk Jim always wanting a ride home. Nope, we happily accept Jenny...even after I drunkenly gave 'her' my cell number, which she has been using with great aptitude. Jenny generally calls when she's at the bar playing, usually asking if we are coming down. I typically get the voicemail and sometimes call her back, sometimes not and sometimes, I even call her to let her know we're there when she's not, to return the courtesy. I say that mostly because I don't want to appear like an asshole. Something happened to me today at work that I'm unsettled about. Not in a 'They're coming to get you Barbara' kind of way, but in the kind of way you used to feel when you found out someone had a crush on you and you didn't like them back...the "Oh fuck, now what am I supposed to do?" feeling. Yeah, Jenny called me on my cell, during working hours, to just "chat." I didn't answer, but when I got the message I had a pang in my stomach, the kind of pang that tells you you are going to have to be fuck to someone you find harmless and you are going to feel like hell for it for a good, long time. Jenny thinks we're 'friends.' At what point during the initial stages of a relationship do you cross over that 'friendly acquaintance' mode and delve into the abyss of friendship? Aren't you giving off cues to this possible partner in crime that you are a willing participant and aren't you, yourself interpreting these moves to make sure no boundaries are being crossed...either too soon or at all? Now granted, I'm a pretty fucking friendly fucker and I don't give a rat's about most stuff, the insignificant. I'll talk to you, even if you don't have many teeth, that's just how I am. My mother yells at me, telling me I'm 'too nice,' which is a stitch considering where I garnered the behavior from. I just posted this as a response to a friend's blog that included a pro/con list used as a means to make a sizeable decision. Poor guy wasn't asking for my two-cents, but I gave it to him anyway. __________________________________________________________ I will make mention of a life lesson I learned regarding pro/con lists. Read on if you are interested. Pro/Con lists don't work, ever. Why? Beacuse you are comparing subjective apples to subjective oranges. The way I combat this problem when making a big decision is by using my now famous "worst-case scenario" method. For example, I had to decide if I was going to stay in NYC or move to Minneapolis. I had a kickass apartment that I bought not that long before (couple years), a well-paying job, amazing friends in town, my mom was nearby and NYC was a mine-field of opportunity and experience...but I was miserable, I felt trapped in a job I hated, I felt trapped on the island, going to grocery store 2 blocks away took an hour to deal with, too many people, I lived a block between a police station and a hospital, sirens all the time...UGH. In Minneapolis I had my best friend, my kickass brother and his fiance', quiet, two cities to find cool stuff to do, I could have a car, the sky was HUGE, every season but winter was beautiful...but, it was MN. Winters are brutal, I had no job security, unfamiliar town where I knew two people, had no idea where to live or how to deal with living in a non-island city...how would I ever find my way around...everything was terribly unknown. There's no way to make that decision. Apples and oranges, right? Enter the 'Worst-case Scenario' method. What's the worst that could happen? I stay in NYC and I continue to be a miserable fuck, be totally depressed, feel trapped and over-exposed to everything, feel overworked and underappreciated and generally just hate life... OR I could go to Minneapolis, check it out and if I hate it...I can LEAVE. I picked the lesser of evils. Whatever worst-case scenario is more painful, do the other thing. You'll keep perspective and your options will seem SO much more clear. Done. Deal. I rented out my apartment, refinanced with a 3/1 arm to give me enough time in Minneapolis to figure out what I was doing...wound up getting a shitload of rent for it, which funded the mortgage of my brand-new, 1,400sq. foot townhouse, built to my specs, on the wetlands where I had jackrabbits and pheasants in my backyard, sky as far as the eye could see and the most beautiful blue in the world. I lived halfway between my brother and best friend, my old boss kept me on, despite my remote location, I worked from home, bought a BMW from a friend and I've been here ever since...Now I own a house in Minneapolis and am soon-to-be married in October. Worst-Case Scenario :)
